content:
Validator "Mixed 2" and "Limit" are the only ones that check whether a carry-over from the unit seconds can have an impact all the way to the minutes.
That is, assuming:
* M is the sum of minutes from the input
* D is the sum of the first digit (tens) of seconds from the input
* U is the sum of the second digit (units) of seconds from the input

then the following incorrect code will pass all tests but fail the last two validators:
```
print(f'{M+D//6+U//60}:{(D+U//10)%6}{U%10}')
```

It would be great if you could add a test that checked that!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty simple, easy to understand and perfectly doable in less than 5 minutes. Pretty fun overall, but you could do until 9:59 mins, or even XX:XX tens of minutes if you're feeling like you want to have fun (so  you can mix up A:AA times with BB:BB times)
I like it!  There is a minor typo in the last line of the description: "minuts" instead of "minutes".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem is easy to understand.
i like the idea but out of my league

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it's a good clash, a simple but good idea.

The clash lacks any significant programming elements e.g. lists, sets, dictionaries, string manipulation, loops, conditions…

Please add one or more programming elements to your clash, so that it is more than a maths problem.

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback!
I’ve updated the clash to include a loop and string manipulation:
> The input now starts with an integer n followed by n lines, each with a time in minutes:seconds format.
> The player must read all values, split the strings, convert the values, and accumulate the total time.

This ensures that the clash involves basic programming elements like loops, conditions, and string parsing, rather than being a pure math problem.

Let me know if you have further suggestions!
Thank you for reviewing and approving the contribution!
Thank you for reviewing and approving the contribution!

Thank you for the feedback!
I fixed it
Thank you for reviewing and approving the contribution!

Thank you very much for your message.

The point you raised makes perfect sense and had unfortunately slipped under our radar.

I’ve submitted a new test to make sure this case is properly accounted for in the future.

It's better now. A few things to fix:

Input
* Please change "m:s" to "[[m]]{{:}}[[s]]".

Output
* Please change "m:s" to "[[m]]{{:}}[[s]]".

Cases
* Mixed (test): Please remove the extra newline at the end of the input.

* Please revise the last test or the last validator so that they are similar but different.

Thanks.

Thanks for the detailed feedback! I've made all the requested changes:
> Updated input and output formats to use [[m]]{{:}}[[s]]
> Removed the extra newline from the 'Mixed (test)' input
> Adjusted the last test/validator to make them similar but not identical

Let me know if anything else needs tweaking!
